sn35.103:4.1: “Mendicants, Uddaka, Rāma’s son, used to say:
sn35.103:4.2: ‘Here’s the thing: the knowledge master! Here’s the thing: the conqueror of all! Here’s the thing: the boil’s root has been dug out, which was never dug out before!’
sn35.103:4.3: Even though Uddaka, Rāma’s son, was no knowledge master, he said ‘I’m a knowledge master.’ Though he was no conqueror of all, he said ‘I’m conqueror of all.’ And though the boil’s root was not dug out, he said ‘I’ve dug out the boil’s root.’
sn35.103:4.4: Here’s how a mendicant would rightly say:
sn35.103:4.5: ‘Here’s the thing: the knowledge master! Here’s the thing: the conqueror of all! Here’s the thing: the boil’s root has been dug out, which was never dug out before!’
sn35.103:5.1: And how is someone a knowledge master?
sn35.103:5.2: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the six fields of contact’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn35.103:5.3: That’s how a mendicant is a knowledge master.
sn35.103:6.1: And how is a mendicant a conqueror of all?
sn35.103:6.2: It’s when a mendicant comes to be freed without grasping after truly understanding these six sense fields’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn35.103:6.3: That’s how a mendicant is a conqueror of all.
sn35.103:7.1: And how has a mendicant dug out the boil’s root, which was never dug out before?
sn35.103:7.2: ‘Boil’ is a term for this body made up of the four elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
sn35.103:7.3: ‘Boil’s root’ is a term for craving.
sn35.103:7.4: It’s when a mendicant has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
sn35.103:7.5: That’s how a mendicant has dug out the boil’s root, which was never dug out before.
